messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Alan ! Just to let you all know, I found out that this book has been reprinted by Art Media Resoures last year or the year before and is now available
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Alan !

Just to let you all know, I found out that this book has been reprinted
by Art Media Resoures last year or the year before and is now available
at Paragon Books in Chicago.

http://www.paragonbook.com/html/browsesubj/fullcitation.cfm?item=17115

Seems like damn good value for the money.

- Matt



-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: alan bale [mailto:abale@...]
Verzonden: dinsdag 29 april 2003 12:15
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba


There is also 'Pointers & Clues to the Subjects of Chinese & Japanese
Art'
by Edmunds if you can find it, it came out in the 1930s and I don't
think it
has been reprinted.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: [Jim, is there any particular reason you have changed your originally lukewarm opinion of Baird? ] Craig, I m still lukewarm about Baird, but it is in print
messages.messageBody:
[Jim, is there any particular reason you have changed your originally
lukewarm opinion of Baird? ]

Craig,
I'm still lukewarm about Baird, but it is in print and it's fairly cheap. I find myself going back to it when doing research, so I reccomend it to people looking for introductory texts on the subject. It's handy, but still incomplete.

Jim


Also, if you can find it, Joly's "Legend" will be much more useful for
research with a copy of:

Tompkins, John B. and Dorothy C.
People, Places, and Things in Henry Joly's Legend In Japanese Art: An
Analytical Index.
Alexandria 1978, Kirin Books, 217p. Limited Edition of 2000

Expect a copy to set you back at least a couple of hundred $US. Not for
those that can't understand why the index can cost more than the book it
references (at least more than the reprint.)

Craig Harris



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Guys, Thanks for all your help ! I have got myself a mint 1979 edition of Joly s book, expensive though at $250...... But I have seen it as high as $400
messages.messageBody:
Hi Guys,

Thanks for all your help ! I have got myself a mint 1979 edition of
Joly's book, expensive though at $250...... But I have seen it as high
as $400 elswhere.

But the reference is available in here (The Netherlands) for just $49.66
! So if anyone is looking for it, I suggest you do a search for it on
Abebooks.com and you will find that Vanderven in the Netherlands is
selling it.

Should have 1 or 2 copies left.

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Craig Harris [mailto:benkei@...]
Verzonden: dinsdag 29 april 2003 1:57
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba


Matt,

Tsuba kodogu gadai jiten, even though in Japanese, is not too hard to
navigate once you memorize Japanese "alphabetical" order (i.e. hiragana)
as
the topics are laid out in that fashion. Plus it has decent pictures.

[Jim, is there any particular reason you have changed your originally
lukewarm opinion of Baird? ]

Also, if you can find it, Joly's "Legend" will be much more useful for
research with a copy of:

Tompkins, John B. and Dorothy C.
People, Places, and Things in Henry Joly's Legend In Japanese Art: An
Analytical Index.
Alexandria 1978, Kirin Books, 217p. Limited Edition of 2000

Expect a copy to set you back at least a couple of hundred $US. Not for
those that can't understand why the index can cost more than the book it
references (at least more than the reprint.)

Craig Harris

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: You can probably find everything that went on the Ark in Joly s Legends in Japanese Art. It is more or less a must for a kodogu collector. Arnold Frenzel
messages.messageBody:
You can probably find everything that went on the Ark in Joly's Legends in
Japanese Art. It is more or less a must for a kodogu collector.

Arnold Frenzel
afrenzel@...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, In addition to Mike Y s good suggestion here are a couple of additional references in English: Symbols of Japan, Thematic Motifs in Art and Design
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
In addition to Mike Y's good suggestion here are a couple of additional references in English:

Symbols of Japan, Thematic Motifs in Art and Design
Merrily Baird, 2001
Rizzoli International Publications
ISBN 0-8478-2361-X

Legend in Japanese Art
Henri Joly, 1908
Reprinted 1967 Charles. E Tuttle
LCCCN 67-16411

Jim




Hi guys,

Does anyone have a book or a list of all the different animals found on
tsuba and other sword furniture, and their meaning ?

I know quite alot about symbolism in Chinese art, but so far they seem
to be quite different to the Japanese.

- Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Matt, Yes, the book is in Japanese, unfortunately.  I am not aware of a translation of it. Mike Y.
messages.messageBody:
Hi Matt,

Yes, the book is in Japanese, unfortunately. I am not aware of a
translation of it.

Mike Y.

At 11:31 PM 4/26/2003 +0200, you wrote:
>Hi Mike,
>
>I presume this book is in Japanese ? If it is there a translation of it
>?
>
>- Matt
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mike, I presume this book is in Japanese ? If it is there a translation of it ? - Matt ... Van: Mike M. Yamaguchi [mailto:mmyamaguchi@komonjo.com]
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mike,

I presume this book is in Japanese ? If it is there a translation of it
?

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Mike M. Yamaguchi [mailto:mmyamaguchi@...]
Verzonden: zaterdag 26 april 2003 23:17
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba


Matt,

Numata Kanji, _Tsuba kodo~gu gadai jiten_, 3 vols., 1967, would be the
one.

This set was later reissued as a two-volume set in 1988. Here's a
description taken from an eBay listing of the two-vlume set:

""This is a dictionary of artistic theme on kodogu. Each kodogu
(menuki,
fuchi, kashira, kozuka) and tsuba has an artistic theme (i.e., what it
tries to depict), and this "dictionary" attempts to list them all.
Volume
I: Japanese and Chinese historical and legendary people, events, and
places. Volume II: things, animals, and plants. For each theme the
dictionary gives: a) the name by which the theme is known; b) detailed
description of the theme; and c) photo plate(s) of work(s) (mostly
tsuba,
some kodogu) on which the theme is depicted.""

I don't have the set with me to see if they explain the "meaning" of
each
animal, but I am sure the author touches upon it in the description.


Mike Y.


At 10:36 PM 4/26/2003 +0200, you wrote:
>Hi guys,
>
>Does anyone have a book or a list of all the different animals found on
>tsuba and other sword furniture, and their meaning ?
>
>I know quite alot about symbolism in Chinese art, but so far they seem
>to be quite different to the Japanese.
>
>- Matt
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: No worries Ken, I ve got Harry s Book on Kodogu, but have not read all of it yet, so I had not seen the list you mentioned. - Matt ... Van: Kenneth Wilson
messages.messageBody:
No worries Ken, I've got Harry's Book on Kodogu, but have not read all
of it yet, so I had not seen the list you mentioned.

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Kenneth Wilson [mailto:kdw21620@...]
Verzonden: zaterdag 26 april 2003 22:55
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Animals on tsuba


While I'm sure not inclusive, Afu in his kodugo insert
has a listing of common animals/insects etc. In
researching for the mantis, the symbolism is mostly
chinese legends. I believe there is a book out there
on animals and japanese art (perhaps not specefic to
nihonto) but I never owned it or saw it in person.
you could do a amazon search if no one else steps up.
As long as harry doesn't mind, I will share some of
his listing (although check out his site to see if its
not posted already) better yet buy his book.
however, My folks are visiting so I won't be on the
computer long.

messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Numata Kanji, _Tsuba kodo~gu gadai jiten_, 3 vols., 1967, would be the one. This set was later reissued as a two-volume set in 1988.  Here s a
messages.messageBody:
Matt,

Numata Kanji, _Tsuba kodo~gu gadai jiten_, 3 vols., 1967, would be the one.

This set was later reissued as a two-volume set in 1988. Here's a
description taken from an eBay listing of the two-vlume set:

""This is a dictionary of artistic theme on kodogu. Each kodogu (menuki,
fuchi, kashira, kozuka) and tsuba has an artistic theme (i.e., what it
tries to depict), and this "dictionary" attempts to list them all. Volume
I: Japanese and Chinese historical and legendary people, events, and
places. Volume II: things, animals, and plants. For each theme the
dictionary gives: a) the name by which the theme is known; b) detailed
description of the theme; and c) photo plate(s) of work(s) (mostly tsuba,
some kodogu) on which the theme is depicted.""

I don't have the set with me to see if they explain the "meaning" of each
animal, but I am sure the author touches upon it in the description.


Mike Y.
